H0.text: Ensuring that the cabbages are safe for human consumption is the purpose of repeating the investigation in which scientists found that cabbages grown with Fertilizer A grew larger than those grown with Fertilizer B or no fertilizer, and the same results were obtained in a second study.

H1.text: To discover the scientific principle that causes the increased growth is the purpose of repeating the investigation, where scientists found that cabbages grown with Fertilizer A grew bigger than those grown with Fertilizer B or no fertilizer and then repeated the experiment obtaining the same results.

H2.text: To confirm that the observed differences were caused by the fertilizer is the purpose of repeating the investigation in which cabbages grown with Fertilizer A grew larger than those grown with Fertilizer B or with no fertilizer.

H3.text: To determine the difference between the experimental and control groups is the purpose of repeating the investigation, which demonstrated that cabbages grown with Fertilizer A grew larger than those grown with Fertilizer B or no fertilizer at all, and the same result was replicated.

A4.text: For the findings of a study to be reproducible means that results obtained by an experiment or an observational study or in a statistical analysis of a data set should be achieved again with a high degree of reliability when the study is replicated.

A5.text: In recent decades Phase II success has fallen from 28 % to 18 %. A 2011 study found that 65 % of medical studies were inconsistent when re‑tested, and only 6 % were completely reproducible.

A6.text: Repeatability is related to the repetition of the experiment within the same study by the same researchers.

A7.text: In a follow‑up study published in 2015, it was found that 246 out of 394 contacted authors of papers in APA journals did not share their data upon request (62%).

A8.text: Failure of an experiment to produce interesting results may lead a scientist to reconsider the experimental method, the hypothesis, or the definition of the subject.

A9.text: The scientific method is iterative. At any stage, it is possible to refine its accuracy and precision, so that some consideration will lead the scientist to repeat an earlier part of the process.

A10.text: Measurements are usually subject to variation and measurement uncertainty; thus they are repeated and full experiments are replicated to help identify the sources of variation, to better estimate the true effects of treatments, to further strengthen the experiment's reliability and validity, and to add to the existing knowledge of the topic.

A11.text: Blocking reduces known but irrelevant sources of variation between units and thus allows greater precision in the estimation of the source of variation under study.
